[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: The human neck is composed of muscles, tendons, and vertebrae. It's relatively soft and compliant, but also structurally sound. I estimate the mass of the section of the neck being manipulated is relatively low, about 1 kg. The coefficient of friction between the robot gripper and the skin is assumed to be around 0.6.
- Environmental Factors: The primary environmental factor is gravity.
- The relevant object is the neck which is composed of muscle and bone has mass 1 kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.6.
- The surface of interaction is the skin which is compliant and fleshy has a static friction coefficient of 0.6 with the object.
- Contact Types: The contact will be a pinch grasp, where the gripper is gently holding the neck. There will also be surface contact with the neck as the gripper massages the area.
- Motion Type: The motion will be a combination of linear motion (sliding/stroking) and rotational motion (kneading).
- Contact Considerations: To maintain contact with the neck during the massage, the robot will need to exert force in the Z-axis and Y-axis. The grasping force also ensures the neck remains in the grip.
- Motion along axes: the robot exerts motion in a "combination" fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes.
- Task duration: I am assuming a duration of 10 seconds.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Mass of neck section being manipulated: m = 1 kg; Coefficient of static friction: μ = 0.6; Acceleration due to gravity: g = 9.81 m/s^2.
- Relevant equations: Frictional force: F_friction = μ * F_normal
- Relevant assumptions: The neck is treated as a rigid body for force calculations, but compliance is considered for safety and gentleness. The grasping force is sufficient to prevent slippage during the massage.
- Computations: The normal force is equal to the force applied by the gripper. Considering the coefficient of static friction between gripper and neck to be 0.6, the force applied by the gripper to massage the neck should be such that frictional force is greater than or equal to the gravitational force: F_friction >= F_gravity --> μ * F_normal >= m * g --> 0.6 * F_normal >= 1 * 9.81 --> F_normal >= 16.35 N.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to generate linear stroking motions to massage the neck, the robot must exert positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 2 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon maintaining contact with the neck and the need to move in the direction roughly orthogonal to the x axis, the robot must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 1 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to maintain a grasping force and normal contact force, the robot must exert positive force along the Z-axis with magnitude 16.35 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to make a rolling motion along the neck the robot must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0.1 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to avoid any bending around the neck to avoid injury, the robot must exert angular no torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon avoiding any rotation around the neck and body, the robot must exert angular no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0 N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force: Based on the need to grasp the neck gently but firmly, to prevent slipping during the massage and using a safety factor, the grasping force should be 16 to 20 N .

```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The neck is composed of muscles and bone, with an estimated mass of 1 kg and a friction coefficient of 0.6 with the gripper."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "The robot will apply a stroking and kneading motion to the neck, with adjustments along the x, y, and z axes to maintain contact and provide pressure."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [2, 1, 16.35, 0.1, 0, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 18
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 10
```

[end of motion plan]

- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."

5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
